summary: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] (born Catherine Elizabeth Middleton; 9 January 1982) is a member of the British royal family. [0] is married to William, Prince of Wales, heir apparent to the British throne.Born in Reading, [0] grew up in Bucklebury, Berkshire. [0] was educated at St Andrew's School and Marlborough College before studying art history at the University of St Andrews in Scotland, where [0] met William, Prince of Wales, heir apparent to the British throne in 2001. [0] held several jobs in retail and marketing and pursued charity work before their's engagement was announced in November 2010. their married on 29 April 2011 at Westminster Abbey. their have three children: George, Charlotte, and Louis.[0] holds patronage with over 20 charitable and military organisations including the Anna Freud Centre, Action for Children, SportsAid, and the National Portrait Gallery. [0] undertakes projects through the Royal Foundation, with [0]'s charity work focusing on issues surrounding early childhood care, addiction, and art. To encourage people to discuss people's mental health problems, [0] envisioned the mental health awareness campaign Heads Together, which [0] launched with William, Prince of Wales, heir apparent to the British throne and brother-in-law Prince Harry in April 2016. The media have called [0]'s impact on British and American fashion the "Kate Middleton effect".  Time listed [0] as one of the 100 Most Influential People in the World in 2011, 2012 and 2013 and as a finalist in 2018. On 9 September 2022, [0] became Princess of Wales when William, Prince of Wales, heir apparent to the British throne was created Prince of Wales by William, Prince of Wales, heir apparent to the British throne's father, King Charles III.

Early life, education and career: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was born on 9 January 1982 at the Royal Berkshire Hospital in Reading into an upper-middle-class family. [0] was baptised at St Andrew's's Bradfield, a local parish church, on 20 June 1982. [0] is the eldest of three children born to Michael Middleton (b. 1949) and his wife, Carole (née Goldsmith; b. 1955), a former flight dispatcher and flight attendant respectively at British Airways. In 1987, his wife, Carole (née Goldsmith; b. 1955), a former flight dispatcher and flight attendant respectively at British Airways founded Party Pieces, a privately held mail order company that sold party supplies and decorations, which collapsed into administration in 2023.By the early 20th century, an upper-middle-class family had married into British aristocracy and benefited financially from trust funds which an upper-middle-class family had established over a century ago. [0]'s an upper-middle-class family relatives, including her great-grandfather Richard Noël Middleton and his wife Oliveher great-grandfather Richard Noël Middleton and his wife Olive's , played host to members of the British royal family in the 1920s through to the 1940s. his wife, Carole (née Goldsmith; b. 1955), a former flight dispatcher and flight attendant respectively at British Airways's family are descended from coal miners, and have been described as working-class. [0] has a younger sister, Philippa, and a younger brother, James.an upper-middle-class family moved from Bradfield Southend, Berkshire, to Amman, Jordan, in May 1984, where [0] attended an English-language nursery school. When an upper-middle-class family returned to Berkshire in September 1986, [0] was enrolled aged four at St Andrew's. [0] boarded part-weekly at St Andrew's's in [0]'s later years. In 1995, an upper-middle-class family moved to the village of Bucklebury where [0] studied at Downe House School. [0] was a boarder at Marlborough College, a co-educational boarding school in Wiltshire, where she showed talent in sports and was captain of the women's field hockey team. While at Marlborough College, a co-educational boarding school in Wiltshire, where she showed talent in sports and was captain of the women's field hockey team, [0] underwent an operation on the left side of [0]'s head, reportedly to remove a lump. [0] obtained three A-Levels in 2000, with an 'A' in mathematics, an 'A' in art, and a 'B' in English.Despite being offered a seat at the University of Edinburgh, [0] took a gap year, studying at the British Institute of Florence in Italy and travelling to Chile to participate in a Raleigh International programme. [0] worked as a deckhand at the Port of Southampton in the summer preceding university. [0] subsequently enrolled at the University of St Andrews in Fife, Scotland, studying art history. [0] briefly studied psychology before focusing solely on art history. [0] worked part-time as a waitress during [0]'s studies. While attending university, [0] achieved a gold Duke of Edinburgh Award. [0] was an active member of The Lumsden Club, which held fundraisers and community projects each year. In 2005, [0] graduated from the University of St Andrews in Fife, Scotland with an undergraduate MA (2:1 Hons) in art history.In November 2006, [0] commenced part-time work for twelve months as an accessory buyer with the clothing chain Jigsaw. In 2007, [0] curated a photography exhibition to mark the book launch of "Time to Reflect", by Alistair Morrison, to raise funds for UNICEF. In 2008, [0] made several trips to Naomi's House Hospice, where [0] brought gifts and read to children. Later that year, [0] organised an '80s-themed roller disco fundraiser which raised £100,000, split between Oxford Children's Hospital, for the construction of Tom's Ward to treat pediatric cancer, and Place2Be, an organisation which provides mental health counselling to school children. [0] also worked until January 2011 at the family business in catalogue design and production, marketing, and photography. While working for the family business, [0] launched the family business's junior brand for toddlers, and began working with the Starlight Children's Foundation, which helps terminally ill youth, providing party essentials for sick children. [0] also helped coordinate the Boodles Boxing Ball, which raised money for the Starlight Children's Foundation, which helps terminally ill youth, providing party essentials for sick children.Prior to [0]'s marriage, [0] lived in an apartment owned by [0]'s in Chelsea, London alongside [0]'s sister, which was estimated to be worth £1–1.4 million. In 2018, [0]'s total net worth was estimated between £5–7.3 million, the majority of which was from [0]'s .

Personal life.Pre-wedding relationship with Prince Wil: [0] is our person to focus on. In 2001, [0] met Prince William while they were students in residence at St Salvator's Hall at the University of St Andrews. [0] reportedly caught Prince William's eye at a charity fashion show at the University of St Andrews in 2002 when [0] appeared on the stage wearing a see-through lace dress. they began dating in 2003. During they's second year, [0] shared a flat with Prince William and two other friends. From 2003 till 2005, they resided at Balgove House on the Strathtyrum estate with two roommates. In 2004, they briefly split but later rekindled their relationship.After [0]'s graduation, [0] and [0]'s were faced with intensive tabloid press scrutiny. [0] attended Prince William's Passing Out Parade at the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst on 15 December 2006.  In April 2007, they ended their relationship. On 17 May 2008, [0] attended the wedding of Prince William's cousin Peter Phillips to Autumn Kelly in Prince William's stead, and met Queen Elizabeth II for the first time.[0] attended the Order of the Garter procession at Windsor Castle in June 2008, where  Prince William was made a Royal Knight of the Garter. On 19 July 2008, [0] was a guest at the wedding of Lady Rose Windsor and George Gilman while Prince William was away on military operations in the Caribbean, serving aboard HMS Iron Duke. In June 2010, they moved into a cottage on the Bodorgan Estate in Anglesey, Wales, where Prince William resided during Prince William's RAF search-and-rescue training and subsequent career.
Personal life.Marriage and children: [0] is our person to focus on. Estimates of the global audience for her wedding ranged around 300 million or more, whilst 26 million watched her wedding live in Britain alone. [0]'s wedding dress was designed by Sarah Burton at Alexander McQueen. Upon [0]'s , [0] assumed the style "Her Royal Highness The Duchess of Cambridge". Middleton and Prince William was given the country home, Anmer Hall, on the Sandringham Estate, as a wedding gift from the Queen. [0] keeps bees on the grounds of the country home, Anmer Hall, on the Sandringham Estate. Following Middleton and Prince William's 2011, Middleton and Prince William used Nottingham Cottage as Middleton and Prince William's London residence. Middleton and Prince William moved into the four-storey, 20-room Apartment 1A at Kensington Palace in 2013. Renovations took 18 months at a cost of £4.5 million. Kensington Palace became Middleton and Prince William's main residence in 2017, moving from the country home, Anmer Hall, on the Sandringham Estate. In 2022, it was announced that Middleton and Prince William, along with Middleton and Prince William's children, would move to Adelaide Cottage in Windsor. Middleton and Prince William officially moved into Adelaide Cottage in Windsor in September 2022.On 3 December 2012, St James's Palace announced that [0] was pregnant with [0]'s first child. announced was made earlier in the pregnancy than is usual as [0] had been admitted to King Edward VII's Hospital suffering from hyperemesis gravidarum, a severe form of morning sickness. [0] remained in King Edward VII's Hospital for three days. Prince George was born at St Mary's Hospital in London on 22 July 2013. hyperemesis gravidarum, a severe form of morning sickness returned with the subsequent pregnancies, forcing [0] to cancel [0]'s official engagements. [0] gave birth to Princess Charlotte on 2 May 2015 and to Prince Louis on 23 April 2018. Prince George was third in the line of succession to the British throne, while Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis were fourth and fifth, respectively, at the times of Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis's births. Middleton and Prince William [0] have owned two English Cocker Spaniels, named Lupo and Orla.

Charity work.Patronages and interests: [0] is our person to focus on. Following [0]'s marriage, [0] assumed royal duties and commitments in support of the British monarch. Charity work.Mental health advocacy: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] has tackled issues surrounding mental health and disabilities. [0] has previously made visits to charities and hospitals such as St Thomas' Hospital and the Maurice Wohl Clinical Neuroscience Institute to spend time with mothers and children who deal with mental health and disabilities.  [0] has also been credited with raising national awareness of children's mental health; Benita Refson, president of Place2Be, has praised [0]'s work, saying that [0] would "shine the spotlight on child mental health", while Peter Fonagy, CEO of the Anna Freud Centre has called [0]'s one of the most important figures in the field, and stated that "to the millions of children who have been suffering in silence, [0] is the millions of children who have been suffering in silence's voice". Charity work.Early years and childhood development: [0] is our person to focus on. Ancestry: [0] is our person to focus on. The Princess of Wales's father is Michael Francis Middleton, son of Captain Peter Francis Middleton, who, along with their forebears, were from Leeds, West Yorkshire. Robert Lacey describes The Princess of Wales's father's family as having aristocratic ties, with Florence Kitson, Lady Airedale (1868–1942) being The Princess of Wales's father's distant relative. Catherine's paternal great-grandmother Olive Christiana Middleton (née Lupton) and Catherine's paternal great-grandmother Olive Christiana Middleton (née Lupton)'s cousin the Baroness von Schunck (née Kate Lupton) were members of the Lupton family who are described as landed gentry and as such, were invited to the coronation of King George V and Queen Mary in 1911. Four successive generations of [0]'s ancestors had lived at Potternewton Hall Estate, the family seat, including Catherine's paternal great-grandmother Olive Christiana Middleton (née Lupton), Catherine's paternal great-grandmother Olive Christiana Middleton (née Lupton)'s , his mother, educator Frances Elizabeth Lupton and his mother, educator Frances Elizabeth Lupton's father, epidemiologist and surgeon Thomas Michael Greenhow.[0]'s maternal ancestors, the Harrisons, were working-class labourers and miners from Sunderland and County Durham. Ancestors through [0]'s maternal line include Sir Thomas Conyers, 9th Baronet (1731–1810), who was a descendant of Edward IV through Edward IV's illegitimate daughter Elizabeth Plantagenet. Other paternal ancestors include Sir Thomas Fairfax (1475–1520) and Sir Thomas Fairfax (1475–1520)'s wife Anne Gascoigne, who was a descendant of Edward IV.
